content.description: Low-angled slab to a steeper section at the top.
content.location: Left of Dike Walk on a separate formation.

content.description:
If this is your route FA let me know the name.

Shares the first few bolts with dike walk then stays a few feet to the right. and finishes with its own anchors. I found the first couple bolts to be the crux and then again at the end just before the anchors. The first flake is crumbling and with time will make the first moves more challenging.

I did a lieback and then transitioned into a crack climb.  When the crack runs out near the top you finish with some committed smearing. This was at the top of my climbing ability so explore different approach and post if you find a better way. Climb on!
content.protection: 5 bolts, chain anchor. The crux midway up is well protected with closely spaced bolts.
content.location:
To climbers right of Dike walk.

34.482108, -117.131502

climbs.name: Dike Walk
climbs.fa: Bill Holder and Jim Voss, Winter 2013/2014

content.description: Slabby face and then move left onto the dike after clipping the 4th bolt. Surf the dike upwards and over a juggy roof to anchors.
content.location: The middle route on the formation.

content.description: This is the really awesome looking roof just to the left of Dike Walk. The roof has great jugs and a perfectly placed bolt to avoid a big potential dangerous whipper!
content.location: Don't forget about the jug! it is really hard to find when you are directly under the roof, but once you hit it all the worries go away
